page.title: 12THE RECTORY
page.content: The house was built in the early nineteenth century and was called the Rectory. There is a brass plaque built into the wall in one of the rooms, put in at the time of building - it reads - 'If thou chance for to find a house to thy mind and built without thy cost, Be good to the poor as God gives thee shore and then my labours not lost'. The water used in the house was pumped from a well in the cellar by means of a donkey engine, there was a hand pump in the sink. The cellar is divided into four areas each with its original stone shelves on which the wine was stored. It was kept cool by a drainpipe running from the roof to the cellar and into a well.The foundations of the house go down three metres and the walls are 50cm thick.
